notes.title: A paper/book should be read in multiple passes
notes.body:
#reading #learning #zettelkasten

An article/paper/book should be read in multiple passes for the best extraction of information.
The point of reading in many passes is to maximize the time efficiency when reading.   


## The three passes
[keshav] suggested that reading can be divided into three passes, that cover from high-level ideas to low-level details.
### Inspectional reading
The first pass should establish the context around the article.
[keshav] suggested that 5-10% of the time should be spent on this.

This step may have the following goals:
- *Establishing context*: What is the background of this paper? What is the previous work, and what comes after this?
- *Relavancy*: How is this related to your research? 
- *Importance*: Is this worth reading? If not then it is a waste of time to read the article.
- *Usefulness*: What information do you want to extract from this paper? 
- *The main arguments*: that are the arguments of the paper/article? This helps establish the mental model before going into more detailed reading.

In this step, it is also important to remember the  [[b740rhio|hourglass structure of information]], so spend more time on the beginning and the end of the section.


### Detailed reading
While doing the detailed reading, we should pay attention to the main arguments of the paper. For instance, what argument/idea is this particular paragraph/sentence supporting? Is it a convincing argument? What other ideas does it contradict?

### Synthesis


## Reference
[keshav]: https://web.stanford.edu/class/ee384m/Handouts/HowtoReadPaper.pdf

notes.title: AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV)
notes.body:
#sev #virtualization #tee #amd

AMD's Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV) enables TEEs at the granularity of virtual machines. 

# Memory encryption
The CPU employs a secure processor (SP) that transparently encrypts/decrypt data when they are written into the memory pages of the encrypted VMs.

Encryption is performed with a per-cVM key maintained by the CPU,c called the VM encryption key (VEK). It is indexed by the ASID of the VM.

A flag called the c-bit (bit 47) indicates whether a page should be encrypted or not. The c-bit is stored in *both* the host PTEs and the guest PTEs. Its effect is determined from the combination of the two c-bit in gPT and NPT.

|             | host c-bit               |                          |
|-------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|
| guest c-bit | 0                        | 1                        |
|-------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|
| 0           | not encrypted            | encrypted with host key  |
| 1           | encrypted with guest key | encrypted with guest key |



# SEV-ES
The original design of SEV does not encrypt the VM states upon VM exit. This leads to attacks that can extract information from the VM based on the register state.

SEV-Encrypted State (ES) solve this issue by also encrypting the VM states upon VMEXIT. It splits the virtual machine control block (VMCB) into two areas, a control area and a save area (VMSA). The VMSA is encrypted with the VEK upon VMEXIT.

## Automatic and non-automatic exits.
Now, every exit from the guest into the hypervisor (`VMEXIT`) is categorized into Automatic Exit (AE) and Non-automatic Exit (NAE). 

AE consists of basically all interrupts that are trigger by the hypervisor. Since these interrupt does not require knowledge of VM register state, all of VM registers will be encrypted and stored into the VMSA.

NAE are the remaining exits, i.e., faults triggered by the VM. Faults can be triggered by the hardware exception such as page fault, or executing a privilege instruction (e.g., write into CR3). 
In this case, the guest might want to share some register states with the hypervisor.

Hence, a `VC` exception (VMM Communication Exception) is generated by the CPU, with the cauuse of exception. The VM then invoke the handler to handle the fault. The handler can copy the selected VM registers into a  shared page, called the  Guest Hypervisor Communication Block (GHCB), which is non-encrypted. It then triggers an AE with a call to  `VMGEXIT`, so that the host can serve the fault.

# SEV-SNP
## Mapping integrity protection
SEV-Secure Nested Paging (SNP) adds integrity protection to SEV, that protect the encrypted pages from replaying (replaced with an old page), being mapped to two regions, and being remapped.

It uses an Reseve Page Mapping (RMP), which is a table maintained by the hardware to keep the mapping metatada for each physical pages.
All memory write accesses look up the RMP to verify the mapping correctness.

Even with the RMP mapping protection, a malicious VMM could still tammper with the permission flags in the page table entries @qin2023protecting. For instance, a malicious hypervisor can overwrite the present bit in the NPT, that indicate wheter the page is inside memory. When the VM access the page, a nested page fault will be trigger.


## VMPL
SEV-SNP also includes the Virtual Machine Privilege Level (VMPL) security mechanism. It adds privilege levels within the encrypted VM.


Hecate @ge2022hecate uses this feature to implement an in-VM hypervisor that handle the VM-VMM interactions for an unmodified, un-enlighteneda OS. 
It put the hypervisor in VMPL layer 0, and the guest VM in VMPL level 4, then have the VMM forwards all faults into the in-VM VMM for handling.

# I/O operations in SEV
See [[zmt276jl]].

# Related notes
- [[d3nt6uix]]
- [[s16ct1rj]]

notes.title: Accessing user memory from Kernel
notes.body:
#linux

Linux provides `__user` annotation to mark userspace pointers. *Transfer functions* such as `copy_from_user` can only operate on those pointers. User pointers are always compared against userspace address space to avoid kernel pointers. An example of `get_user`:
``` assembly
.text
ENTRY(__get_user_1)
    mov PER_CPU_VAR(current_task), %_ASM_DX
    cmp TASK_addr_limit(%_ASM_DX),%_ASM_AX
    jae bad_get_user
    ASM_STAC
1:  movzbl (%_ASM_AX),%edx
    xor %eax,%eax
    ASM_CLAC
    ret
ENDPROC(__get_user_1)

bad_get_user:
    xor %edx,%edx
    mov $(-EFAULT),%_ASM_AX
    ASM_CLAC
    ret
END(bad_get_user)

_ASM_EXTABLE(1b,bad_get_user)
```

The first two instructions check the pointer against the process descriptor to make sure it's not pointer from usersapce. Then it disable SMAP (ASM_STAC) and access userspace memory (at 1: block)

notes.body:
#programming #kernel #c #cxx



# Creating a mask with all N bit set
```c
#define mask(N) (1UL << N) - 1
```
For example, if N = 3, then the first shift will create ` 1000`. When subtracted by 1 bit, the result will be `111`

# Checking if the Nth bit is set in a word

```c
#define check(word, N) (word & (1UL << N))
```
# Clearing the Nth bit
```c
#define clear(word, N) (word & ~(1UL << N))
```
# Check if a number is power of 2 
The key property is that if the number is the power of 2, it only has m bit set in the leftmost bit.
```c
#define is_power_of_2(n) ((n & (n - 1)) == 0)
```

notes.title: Bits in page table entries
notes.body:
#os #architecture


# Present flag
The *present* flag indicates that there exists a backing physical frame for this page table entry. If the present bit is not set, a page fault will be triggered.


# Access and dirty flags
On x86, bit 5 is the *accessed* flag, and bit 6 is the *dirty* flag.

The _accessed_ flag is set when a page is accessed by the CPU during address translation. The *dirty* flag is set when a page is written by the CPU. 

After being set, these flags need to be cleared by the software.

The dirty bit indicates that page must be written to the disk before the frame can be reused for other pages. Else, the page content is unchanged, so it is safe to reuse the page [standford-paging].

# Bits in page table entries
#os #architecture


# Present flag
The *present* flag indicates that there exists a backing physical frame for this page table entry. If the present bit is not set, a page fault will be triggered.


# Access and dirty flags
On x86, bit 5 is the *accessed* flag, and bit 6 is the *dirty* flag.

The _accessed_ flag is set when a page is accessed by the CPU during address translation. The *dirty* flag is set when a page is written by the CPU. 

After being set, these flags need to be cleared by the software.

The dirty bit indicates that page must be written to the disk before the frame can be reused for other pages. Else, the page content is unchanged, so it is safe to reuse the page [standford-paging].

notes.title: CAP-VMs: Capability-Based Isolation and Sharing in the Cloud
notes.body:
#literature #capabilities #vm #os #cheri #ipc #libos #container
[@sartakov2022capvms]

## One sentence summary
The paper built a container-like isolation abstraction on top of CHERI architecture for efficient sharing on and isolation.

## Context
### Containers vs. Virtual machines
Containers and Virtual machines both have disadvantages for implementing isolation and sharing. See [[h3manv25]]. 

### Capabilities
Cheri capabilities enable in-process compartmentalization with the hybrid capability model.

### Contributions
This paper proposed the best of both world with CHERI capabilities: *cVM*, new VM-like abstraction for cloud isolation with efficient, single-address space sharing.
- Communication between cVMs bypass the OS with new in-process capabilities abstractions for trusted safe ipc.
- Compatible with existing applications with the *hybrid* capability model. Only a subset of libC, the library OS, and the intravisor need to be capability-aware.
- No namespace isolation is required, since the isolation boundary is in-process through capabilities. The OS is only needed for I/O, synchronization, execution context (similar to a VM).

## System overview
The system introduces 2 layers of isolation. A *library OS* provides namespace isolation for and provides OS primitives for the cVMs. An *intravisor* manage cVMs instances, enable cross-communication and other primitives.

The program interacts with the libOS through the syscall interface provided by the musl libc. LibOS interact with intravisor through hostcall interface. Both interfaces are capability-ware.

## APIs
A set of APIs is provided to manage cVM and facilitate their communications.

CP_FILE-based interfaces enable file-like access to other cVM memory through capability invocation.
A cVM registers shared memory to be shared across other cVMs with a key. Other cVMs read and write into the CP-FILE obtained with the same key.

CP_CALL-based interfaces allows for capability-based registration and invocation of external functions.

## Capability management
The system revoke CAP_STORE from capabilities, preventing them from being stored into memory outside of the intra.

notes.body:
#fleeting #idea
 

# Background
Software defenses such as DFI/CPI/CFI see the program at one unit.

Efforts in compartmentalization brings the boundary to within the program. 


# Main arguments
Existing software hardening techniques are not compartment-aware, so they miss classes of attacks on compartment interfaces.

Making them compartment-aware requires some static / runtime analysis at the boundary.


# Compartment-aware CFI
CFI type matching + compartment-aware narrowing for cross-compartment indirect calls
e.g., A site can only call type B from compartment X.

# Compartment-aware DFI
Assuming data isolation between domains.
DFI only for cross-domain objects.
- Use static analysis to determine subset of sensitive objects.
- We enforce DFI on them.

This has sanitizing effect, remove CIV.

notes.title: Confused deputy
notes.body:
#capabilities #compartmentalization

Confused deputy happens when a high-privilege system is tricked into perform a certain action on behalf of a lower privilege system.

## An example
The example  used in the original paper [@hardy1988confused] is a compiler program. A user invoke the compiler with the name of the input file to compile a program, and also an output file to receive statistics.
The compiler is given the authority to write into its home directory. Let's say there is another file in the home directory of the compiler that contains the billing information. A malicious user of the compiler can invoke it to trick the compiler into writing into the billing file, since it is within the authority of the compiler.

In a sense, confused deputy happens due to the *ambient authority*. In the compiler case, the compiler user obtains more authority than needed (access to the whole home directory) to perform it job (read input, write output). 

To solve this problem, a naive solution would be to switch the authority of the compiler (through some system call) to that of the invoker. However, such a system would lead to complexity when there is a high amount of authorities, and also hard to generalize [@hardy1988confused]. 

## Interface vulnerabilities
Interface vulnerabilities is a manifestation of confused deputy problem, where different mutually distrusting entities interacts with each other through exposed interfaces [@lefeuvre2022assessing]. For instance, a malicious process can exploit the system call interface to tricking the kernel into corrupting itself. Interface vulnerabilites is also there at other boundaries, such as libraries, in-process compartments [@lefeuvre2022assessing].

notes.title: Containers vs. Virtual machines
notes.body:
#vm #container #cloud #ipc #os #virtualization

Containers and virtual machines ([[s16ct1rj]]) are two main isolation primitives when it come to cloud isolation.

Virtual machines provides strong isolation between application components and a small TCB a small hypervisor need to be trusted. 
However, data sharing between VMs is challenging and commonly have high overheads (see [@yasukata2023exitless]).

On the other hand, containers allows application components to share the underlying OS. This enable richer IPC mechanisms for better data sharing. This comes at the cost of larger TCB: a shared OS have to implement namespace isolation and complex IPC primitives [@sartakov2022capvms]. 

Still, sharing is coarse-grained in both of the case, since the IPC interfaces are designed at page granularity. 
Sharing is also expensive. VMFUNC-based sharing in VMs have expensive cost of VMEEXIT, which exit-less mechanisms tries to achieve [@yasukata2023exitless].

Controlled-channel attack refers to attacks launched by the higher-privilege system against the lower privilege one. The confidential lower-privilege system (SGX, VM) lacks capabilities (e.g., paging, file access), and need to request the higher-privilege system (OS, hypervisor) for resources. This scenario happen especially in confidential execution environment, where the protected program do not trust the underlying infrastructure, or cloud service provider (CSP).

notes.title: Controlled-channel attacks against SEV
notes.body:
#controlled-channel #side-channel #sev #tee

# Nested page fault side-channels
Virtualization hardware enables two-stage translation process from gVA to gPA, and from gPA to hPA through the nested page table (NPT) ([[d3nt6uix]]). This is the same in SEV. Although there is no official documentation, many paper indicate that hypervisor cannot intercept guest page faults (gPF) and look for faulting address.

Page fault attacks in SEV is similar to the controlled-channel attacks on SGX @xu2015controlledchannel. 
The hypervisor can unset the present bit (`P` bit) in the NPT for particular physical pages, such that nested page fault (NPF) will be generated when the page is accessed by the VM, which the hypervisor can capture and analyze.

# IO events
Some applications requiring I/O events can leak certain behaviors of the program. For instance, @morbitzer2019extracting, @li2019exploiting use network packets to determine the start/end of a TLS connection, and disk I/O to determine disk encryption operation.


# Related notes
- @li2019exploiting: [[literature/ncfh611p]]

notes.title: Cost of IPC in microkernels
notes.body:
#microkernel #sel4 #ipc #kpti #os

In microkernels such as sel4, kernel code is kept to the minimum, and most of the system services such as file system, and networking are moved into the userspace as a *system server*. Applications that use those services need to invoke them through *IPCs*.
Since those services are in the userspace in different address spaces, an IPC would consist of:
1. Privilege switch to from application the kernel
2. Process switch to the callee process
3. Privilege switch to the callee  
2. Process switch back to the caller  process
4. Privilege switch from kernel to the caller

## Overhead analysis
[@gu2020armonizing] (see [[literature/2a7l7odo]]) performed a study of the source of overheads of such IPC. SQLite3 is run on Zircon and seL4 microkernels. It is found that total IPC time is 79% [of](2024-05-19_of.md) the time on Zircon and 44% of the time on seL4 (with KPTI).

The overheads of each component are also studied in the following table. 

|   Parts  | w/o KPTI    | w/ KPTI    |
| ---------------- | --------------- | --------------- |
| Privilege switch    | 158    | 690    |
|  Process switch    | 295    | included above    |
| Others   | 277   | 320   |
| Total   | 730   | 1010   |

*Privilege switch* is the overhead of a syscall instruction.
*Process switch* is mostly changing the page table by writing into the CR3 register (about 270 cycles). With KPTI enabled, an additional page table switch needs to be added to every user-to-kernel privilege switch, which adds another layer of overheads. 
Additionally, there are also other types of overheads such as permission checks, and capabilities checks.

notes.title: Detecting bugs in Rust
notes.body:
#rust


# Rudra
Rudra @bae2021rudra analyzes Rust HIR and MIR to have a *generic type-aware* analysis.
Generic type-awareness is necessary, because a certain bugs only happen for the implementation of specific types.

```rust
fn double_drop<T> (mut val: T){
  unsafe {ptr::drop_in_place(&mut val);}
  drop(val);
}
double_drop(123); // no violation since drop on integer is no-op
double_drop(vec![1, 2, 3]); // double-free happens
```

More specifically, Rudra consider a generic function having bugs, if any of the instantiation has a safety bug.

## Unsafe Dataflow Checker
This checker simply find if their exists a dataflow from the start of lifetime bypass to a suspicious function call. The hope is to find dataflwo from unsafe into functions that might `panic`, or functions that might implicitly requires some higher-order invariants (but not upholded by the unsafe caller).

It is suprising that this simple heuristic helps finds a lot of bugs. On the other hand, it has very high false positive rate (53.3% precision on highest precision). 
Moreover, this kind of heuristic is coarse-grained, it does not try to identify the *root cause* of the bug, but instead finds pattern that commonly have bugs,and rely on the programmer instead instead to filter out the bugs.


There are two heuristics used by this checker,  to determine the lifetime bypass locations, and to determine suspicious function calls.

### Suspicious function calls
This check marks all *unresolvable generic function call* as suspicious. Unresolvable functions are functions that their definitions cannot be found without precise type parameters. 
An example was:
```rust
fn foo<T>(reader: T)
  where T: Reader {
  reader::read();
}

```

In this case, to know the definition of `read()`, the type of `reader` must be known, but it is available at runtime. On the other hand, `Vec<T>::push()` has implementation of `push()` implemeted for all possible type `T`.

The author finds that those unresolable function are where programmers usually make mistake, since they have to *speculate* about the function behaviors.





### Lifetime bypass locations
There are six classes of lifetime bypasses:
- Unintialized value (created by extending `Vec` with `Vec::set_len()`)
- Duplicating lifetime (e.g., `mem::read()`)
- Overwriting memory (e.g., `mem::write`)
- Copying values (e.g., buffer copy) (this has the effect of duplicating and overwriting)
- Transmuting a type and its lifetime
- Converting a pointer to a reference

Rudra uses three precision settings:
- High precision only detect uninitialized values (e.g., `Vec::set_len()`)
- Medium precision setting additionally find lifetime bypass using `read()`, `write()`, `copy()`.
- Low precision setting find all `transmute()`a and raw pointer casting.

notes.body:
#assembly #arm

Although there is no push and pop instructions, Arm support addressing modes that can both update and address memory. This can be used to implement stack push and pop
More concretely, post-indexing is used for push, and pre-indexing is used for pop

Pre-indexing update the address register *before* the store, which is essentialy the same as x86 push instruction that decrease the stack pointer, then store the value
``` asm
str x1, [sp, -#16]!
```

Pre-index addressing update the address register after the store. 
``` asm
ldr x1, [sp] #16
```

Source: [Addressing Lab](https://www.cs.uregina.ca/Links/class-info/301/ARM-addressing/lecture.html)

notes.title: Exitless system calls for SGX
notes.body:
#sgx #tee #system-call #performance #rpc

To perform system calls in SGX, the enclave must perform enclave exit and enter through `EEXIT`, `EENTER`. It is found that these two instructions have heavy overheads of about 3,300 and 3,800 cycles @orenbach2017eleos. This is much higher than the overheads of a normal system call, about 250 cycles.

Another cost of SGX is due to page fault, since in an enclave exit also need to be triggered.

# Elos
## RPC for system calls
@orenbach2017eleos proposed using RPC instead to serve system calls on an enclave. The system employs a separated thread in the untrusted part of the application to serve system call. Ocalls in SGX for serving system call is then replaced with RPC to the system call-serving threads. 

Moreover, the system uses Intel Cache Allocation Technology (CAT) to allocate only 25% of the cache to the worker thread, while keeping 75% cache. This avoids LLC pollution.

@orenbach2020autarky, @orenbach2019cosmix also adapts this.

## User-managed virtual memory 
Elos also includes a fine-grained page management system to avoid enclave exit on page faults. The idea is to cache the commonly used pages in the untrusted memory, and serve from it first, instead of relying on the OS.

@orenbach2020autarky, @orenbach2019cosmix also adapts this.

## User-managed virtual memory 
Elos also includes a fine-grained page management system to avoid enclave exit on page faults. The idea is to cache the commonly used pages in the untrusted memory, and serve from it first, instead of relying on the OS.

notes.title: Exploiting Unprotected I/O Operations in AMDs Secure Encrypted Virtualization
notes.body:
#literature #side-channel #sev
@li2019exploiting


# Summary
The paper proposes an attack method that exploits the unprotected I/O operations in AMD SEV. Here, *unprotected* means that the I/O operations (MMIO and DMA) must be performed on unencrypted memory that is visible by the hypervisor. The paper shows that by replacing ciphertext blocks in the VM memory, the hypervisor can create trick the VM into encrypting and decrypting arbitrary data, hence encryption/decryption oracles.


# Attack overview
## Encryption oracle
The target of the attack is an SSH service running inside a cVM. While the ssh packets are encrypted, due to unprotected I/O [[zmt276jl]], the hypervisor can observe and modify the TCP and IP headers.

Briefly, the attack finds the *encrypted* page that contains the packet to be sent over the I/O channel. It then replaces the encrypted header (16B) with another encrypted block of data, right before the packet is copied into the unencrypted I/O memory observable by the hypervisor. Using this method, a decryption oracle is built that allows the decryption of any memory block.

The attack is performed in three steps: pattern matching, ciphertext replacement, and packet recovery.

### Pattern matching
Pattern matching stage uses the nested page fault side-channel [[qq4qcbos]] to determine which pages are being accessed when the VM serves the SSH packet. The hypervisor first sends an SSH packet to the VM, then clears the present bits in the NPT PTEs.
It collects the sequences of page fault accesses to build a _signature_ of the page accessed from the time of receiving the request, to the time right before sending the packet. It then uses this signature to determine the page containing the `sk_buff` structure that contains the packet.

### Ciphertext replacement
Ciphertext replacement replaces the ciphertext inside the header of the SSH packet and recovers the plaintext result. Since SEV's memory encryption applies a teak function based on the physical address, steps need to be done to recover plaintext:
Assuming the ciphertext $c$ is copied from the address $P_c$. Plaintext must be obtained by:

$m = d \oplus  T(hPA((P_{priv}+16))/16*16) \oplus T(P_c)$ 

Where $d$ is the decrypted text of $c$, T is the tweak function. Essentially, this negates the effect of the teak of the current address and applies the teak of the target location.

### Plaintext recovery
The original plaintext must be recovered so that the attack is stealthy. Since the attack only modifies the header of the SSH packet, which is public, it only needs to predict the content of the current header (replaced by the attack). Here, the ID of the packet is increased by 1 after each response, so it adds that to the response's header.


# Mitigation
The attack in this paper is mitigated by SEV-SNP since the hypervisor cannot write into encrypted memory anymore.

Since SNP did not exist at the time, the paper also suggests other mitigations. One of them is to make the VM encrypts the *entire* packets, and use a trusted proxy server to decrypt the packets, before forwarding them to the client.

notes.title: Failure in ORAM
notes.body:
#oblivious 

In most ORAM algorithms, there is a chance of failure.

The design of ORAM tries to avoid this using some techniques.

# Eviction strategy
## Reversed path eviction
In the eviction phase (Path ORAM and Ring ORAM), blocks are pushed to the tree in the reversed order, starting from the leaves, and ending at the root. The reason for intuition is that blocks at higher levels are more likely to intersect with another path.
For example, in a tree with 3 levels, nodes on the last level (leaf nodes) correspond to only one path. node on the second level can be evicted on 2 paths (1 can be evicted on paths 0 and 1). Nodes on the first level can be evicted on any path.

```
              0
          1       2
      3       4       5
---------------------------
path: 0       1       2
```

## Background Eviction
@ren2013design proposed a *background eviction* strategy. This happens when the free slots in the stash becomes smaller than $Height*BucketSize$, i.e., the minimum free blocks required in an ORAM access.

dummy access is performed on random a path that read blocks into the stash, and opportunistically place blocks back into the tree. At worst, if the path is already filled, or no blocks can be evicted from the stash, the path is simply written back to the tree.

An advantage of this is that the background eviction access pattern is identical to an ORAM access, so attackers cannot know when background eviction happens.


@renconstants also have a *early reshuffling* strategy.

notes.title: Force function inline in LLVM
notes.body:
#llvm

The problem: I'm trying to instrument the program's load and store instruction with wrapper that modify the pointer in the value. Since there are a lot of load/store, and the wrapper is short, I expect inlining would leads to better performance.

I tried to force inline with the function attribute `__attribute__((__always_inline__))` but it did not work. LLVM would not listen.

Luckily `Lib/Transform/Utils/Cloning.h` provide a function call `InlineFunction(CallInst, ...)` when invoked it would try to inline the call instruction. 

Hence I used two step to inline every calls. The first step instrument the function call normally, but store the inserted LLVM's CallInst in an array. After instrumentation is done, I loop through the array to invoke `InlineFunction` on them.

notes.title: HYDRA:The Kernel of a Multiprocessor Operating System
notes.body:
#literature #os #capabilities
@wulf1974hydra



## Noteworthy arguments
### Hierarchical layering limits flexibility: See [[c4icaua4]].
However, maintaining order in a non-hierarchical manner is challenging in traditional systems. HYDRA's capability model enable flexibility by rejecting hierarchical structuring. In HYDRA, a *template* define the security checking mechanism of a procedure, and allows a procedure to *derive* higher capabilities from the argument capabilities (belong to the caller). This way, a callee function might have greater capabilities than the caller, but the caller have no way of obtaining those capabilities by itself. This enable invocation of procedures in any orders, as long as the callee adhere to the rules defined by the system designer.

As a downside, such a system must have the support from the kernel. HYDRA uses a kernel-assisted CALL mechanism. The kernel checks for the parameter capabilities with the according to the security requirements. It then derives new capabilities and place it in the callee's environment. Finally, the kernel transfer the control to the callee function.

### Protection (mechanism) should be separated from security (policy)
The paper argue that the protection mechanism does not necessary grant security. Take password for example, the password checking mechanism does not guarantee that the user will use a strong enough password.

Hence, HYDRA aims to provides primitives (mechanisms) to implements the policy (security), but not to provide  the security by itself.

notes.title: Harmonizing Performance and Isolation in Microkernels with Efficient Intra-kernel Isolation and Communication
notes.body:
#literature #mpk #microkernel #sel4 #os
[@gu2020harmonizing]

## Context
The paper argues that the cost of IPC in microkernels are too high, and proposed using MPK-based domains to reduce the number of context switches during IPCs.
The paper provides a motivation study by profiling the overheads of IPC in common microkernels (see [[i2blyo37#Overhead analysis]]).

### Background
Previous systems use MPK for single address-space isolation.

Previous state-of-the-art [@mi2019skybridge] enables fast IPC by retrofitting VMFUNC., but still have high overheads due to Page table switching

### Contributions
The proposed system tackles three main challenges in the context of microkernels that previous work did not solve. 
- The first is to prevent illegal IPC calls, since intel MPK does not check for permission before executing code. This is solved by secure IPC gates for the specific connections between two specific servers (a *system server* is an application that provides system-level services) in the trusted domain (core kernel). 
- Second is the limited number of domains. The paper designs a *server migration* technique that allows a server to be migrated between userspace (same as normal microkernel) and kernel space.
- Third, due to the server executing in the privileged space, the system needs to prevent it from executing privileged instructions.

notes.title: Hierarchical layering limits flexibility
notes.body:
#capabilities #os

Many systems uses the strict hierarchical layering for resource allocation. In those systems, the rule enforced by the kernel is that 
(1) a process can only allocate resources that it own to its children, 
(2) can only start/stop/remove its own childrens, and 
(3) A process's resources must be returned to its parent when it terminates.
This can be seen in modern UNIX system.

However, [@wulf1974hydra] found that hierarchical layering of a system limits its flexibility. For example, while resource allocation might contains hierarchical layering, as shown above,  the *control* (e.g., starting/stopping subprocesses) need not to have the same hierarchical. 

Also, a strict hierarchical system leads to increasingly privileged system components, and therefore leads to a component that have the "most privileged" only because of it place in the system. This leads to confused deputy problems ([[y9wu5ut7]]) in those components.

#virtualization

A hypervisor, also known as virtual machine monitor (VMM) manage virtual machines. 

It performs interposition ([[s16ct1rj#interposition]]) on a certain *interesting* instructions to *emulate* then, hence *trap-and-emulate*. Those interesting instruction can be:
- Access to hardware devices
- Special instructions (e.g., CPUID)
- Access to important and dangerous registers that have global effect 

Hypervisor works by exploiting modern hardware supports that allows trapping of those important instructions.

## Launching VM
Processor state of the VM is stored in a Virtual Machine Control structure/block (VMCS/VMCB) (see [VMCS](https://shhoya.github.io/hv_vmcsdata.html)). VMCS is a complex structure containing informations related to a VM's state. A pointer to the current VMCS is stored in a dedicated register, loaded with `VMPTRLD` instruction ([VMPTR](https://www.felixcloutier.com/x86/vmptrld.)).

The hypervisor is required to setup the VMCS correctly with necessary information.

The `VMLAUNCH\VMRESUME` instruction is then used to lanch the VM based on the current VMCS.

## Memory management
### Legacy
Previously, all access to physical memory in the Guest need to be interposed and emulated, which causes a lot of overheads. Address translation and paging need to be perform twice.

### Shadow Page Table
To avoid this, Shadow page table (SPT) is a per-VM page table used by the hypervisor to translate guest virtual memory to host physical memory. 
It maintain a copy of the guest page table in a *shadow* page table, and mirror every page table update from the guest. 

This shadow page table is pointed to by CR3, and contains the actual mapping.

Upon a guest page fault (aka, shadow page fault):
- The hypervisor trap it, then forward it to the guest for it to update its page table since there is no entry yet.
- The guest update its page table (which will not be used by hardware translation). This may trigger a real page fault if guest page table is set at Read-only. Here the hypervisor can intercept and update the shadow page table.
- The guest then access the memory. Since the mapping is now contained in the shadow page table, it can access it. 

Note that this process bypass the two-time address translation.

Still, this is expensive when there is a lot of paging in the guest VM, since every page fault in the guest is forwarded to the host.

Nowaday it is still used in nested virtualization.

### EPT/NPT
Extended page table (EPT), aka Nested page table (NPT), is a hardware extension implementing second-level address translation (SLAT). 
Each VM will have an additional extended page table translate from guest physical address (gPAddr) into host physical address (hPAddr).
This extended page table is stored in the VMCS. 
In virtualization mode, the MMU now walk the guest VM page table first to translate gVAddr to gPAddr. Then the MMU, without stopping, translate the second page table in the host. Hence, host page table is *nested* within the guest page table to translate (gPAddr->hVAddr->hPAddr). 
If there is a page fault, the host OS simply update the nested table with the mapping.
This allows more efficient translation.

With the technology, when there is on guest's page fault, there is no exit to the hypervisor; the CPU automatically wals both page table.

For more implementation details of the feature, see [bhyve](https://people.freebsd.org/~neel/bhyve/bhyve_nested_paging.pdf)'s implementation.

# More resources
- [High-level introduction to the Low-Level virtualization](http://haifux.org/lectures/312/High-Level%20Introduction%20to%20the%20Low-Level%20of%20Virtualization.pdf)
- Intel manual?

notes.title: I/O operations in AMD SEV
notes.body:
#sev #io #tee

SEV VMs interacts with virtualized hardware through QEMU. More particularly, QEMU-KVM on the host side will serve I/O requests of the VM.

Supported common I/O operations are PIO, MMIO, DMA.

# DMA
The IOMMU maps DMA-capable I/O buses of hardware devices to the physical memory. Because the IOMMU only supports memory encryption with ASID=0 (host ID), DMA operations must be done on pages that are shared between VM and host. Those pages are called the Software  I/O Translation Look-aside Buffer SWIOTLB.

On a read DMA request from the guest VM, QEMU-KVM instructs the IOMMU to perform DMA transfer from device into the SWIOTLB (e.g., swapping pages from the disk). The guest VM then copy the pages inside SWIOTLB into its own memory.

On a write DMA request, the guest need to copy its data into the SWIOTLB first. QEMU-KVM then commands the IOMMU to transfer those pages to the devices.

# Security
Because I/O is unencrypted, the cVM needs to encrypt the I/O data using the software. If I/O is not corrupted, the hypervisor can corrupt contents (e.g., binary) loaded from the disk into memory. @li2019exploiting shows an example where a malicious hypervisor patches the `sshd` binaries to bypass the authentication.

However, certain types of data cannot be encrypted. For instance, packets for DHF key exchange are not encrypted. 

@li2019exploiting took a closer look at I/O operations that must not be encrypted:
- In network I/O, the header of IP or TCP cannot be encrypted. Hence, the attacker can forge the header.
- In display I/O (e.g., VNC), QEMU-KVM redirects the VGA display from the guest to the VNC protocol.
- Disk I/O can be encrypted with a secret key provisioned by the cVM owner. However, the key is stored in memory and can be extracted using the encryption oracle described in the paper.


# Related notes
- @li2019exploiting: [[literature/ncfh611p]]

notes.title: Idea Compass
notes.body:
#zettelkasten #note-taking

Idea Compass is a thinking tool that helps define how to think about a particular idea. In particular, it is described in [Compass of Zettelkasten Thinking](https://feeei.substack.com/i/48707291/the-compass-of-zettelkasten-thinking) as follows:

>
1.  take one idea (X) and put it in the centre
2. imagine the four compass directions. each direction helps give definition to the idea in different ways.
  - NORTH: *Where does X come from?* what are its origin? what group/category does X belong to? what exists an order of magnitude higher? zoom out. what gave birth to X? what causes X
  - WEST: *What is similar to X?* what other disciplines could X already exist in? what other disciplines could benefit from X? what are other ways to say/do X?
  - SOUTH: *Where can X lead to?* what does X contribute to? what group/category could X be the headline of? what exists an order of magnitude lower? zoom in. what does X nurture?
  - EAST: *What competes with X?* what is the opposite of X? what is X missing? its disadvantage? what could supercharge X?
3. The Zettelkasten structure created around the idea could look something like this:
  - NORTH
    - The Idea
      - SOUTH
      - EAST
      - WEST


Takes the idea of the *idea compass* itself for example. We can start from the NORTH:
- NORTH: *"Where does X come from?"* 
  - This idea comes from the lack of clear instructions for using the zettelkasten [[ae6fatms]] method. For instance, what should an idea contain? How do you connect it with other ideas?
  - Hence, the author introduces a framework for finding the *context* of an idea.
  - SOUTH: *What can X leads to?*
    - This idea helps to discover the context of a Zettelkasten note. More importantly, helps writing notes easier [[cemsxh4n]]
  - EAST: *What competes with X?*
  - WEST: *What is similar to _X?_ [This](https://zettelkasten.de/posts/creative-technique-within-zettelkasten-framework/) introduces another technique called the *knowledge flower* [[dyx2t4oz]] that is more open for interpretation.

notes.title: InkTag: Secure Applications on an Untrusted Operating System
notes.body:
#literature #hypervisor

# Background
At the time of this paper, SGX that have the same functionality but without hypervisor have yet to exist.

Previous system on protection against untrusted OS, OverShadow [@chen2008overshadow] only focus on isolation of memory (code and data) from the OS. This papers provides methods for verifying OS behaviors, allowing the protected program to use OS services securely.







![hologram](../images/hologram.png)







# Main arguments
## Verifying OS behaviors with the hypervisors is more simple than reimplementing OS services inside the hypervisor
- OS services often have simple specifications.
- Only implementing verification in the kernel reduces the TCB of hypervisor.
- The introduced technique called *paraverification* to verify the unstrusted OS. Essentially, the OS is changed to cooperate with the hypervisor for verifiable OS services (e.g., page management). 

## Untrusted OS verification leads to security
- This directly address the Iago Attack [[ns7lcn8t]] where the untrusted OS feeds incorrect values to trusted application.
- InkTag enable crash consistency
- InkTag is able to secure files with defined access control policies. 

# Control flow
The High assurance programs (HAPs) and the operating system interacts through a *untrusted trampoline*. The application first invoke the hypervisor to request system call. The hypervisor switch the control to an untrusted trampoline that actually invoke the system call. 

This allows the untrusted OS to schedule among the untrusted trampolines and other contexts.

NOTE: Not quite understand.

# Memory isolation
InkTag provides two layers of memory isolation: kernel to High assurance programs (HAPs), and between the HAPs.
Memory isolation are provided by EPT virtualization plus paraverfication.
This isolation is maintained from the file system up to the memory pages.

The *object* abstraction represents files. Each object is given a unique ID (*OID*).
An objects consists of *secure pages (S-pages)* that contains metadata about the owner object and the offset within the object (*<OID, offset>*), and also the *hash* of the data (for verification).

## Two EPTs
Two EPTs are used for trusted context (HAPs) and untrusted context (kernel / normal apps). The trusted EPT maps the plaintext S-page physical frames. The untrusted EPT maps the other frames.  
- When OS / untrusted applications access a mapped S-pages in trusted EPT (not mapped in untrusted), the hypervisor unmap it in trusted EPT, take the hash, encrypt the page, then map it to untrusted EPT.
- When HAP access the frame, hypervisor decrypt the page, verify the hash, map it to trusted EPT, unmap it from untrusted EPT. 

## Isolation between HAPs
The hypervisor manage page table updates for HAPs, to enforce access control policies of objects. For normal pages, the OS can map without intervention.

notes.body:
#compartmentalization

[@lefeuvre2022assessing] proposed 8 guidelines for designing safe interface that helps reduce the interface vulnerabilities.

## 1. Clearly segregate resources
This means that each component must be responsible for allocating and freeing their own resources. In other words, they should *not* expose a malloc-like interface to other compartments. Doing so, attackers from a compartment can exploit the allocator (e.g., heap feng shui), or trigger arbitrary use-after-free (if the allocated data is used at both side).

## 2. Always copy cross boundary objects
In other words, never let two compartments concurrently modify data. Doing so leads to TOCTOU issues, and the need of cross-compartment synchronization.


## 3. Simplifying API-crossing objects
APIs should not contains private states of the compartment, since they can easily corrupted.

Moreover, private states are very hard to check for correctness, especially pointer data.

Maintaining immutability of those state is also a hard problem.


## 4. Trusted-components allocates
The trusted component must allocates memory. 

This guideline is to avoid validating may-corrupted data from other components. 
Especially, for strings, since the trusted component allocate, it knows the size of the buffer, so checking NULL-termination is not needed. 

It is not sure if it is applicable to other data except from String. A more generalized version is that the trusted component must allocate memory where the size is unknown.

## 5. Trusted interface functions must be thread-safe
This is to avoid temporal attacks.

## 6. Ordering requirements 
Interface must enforce ordering requirements if possible.


## 7. No sharing of unintialized data
This is to avoid leaking of private data in uninitalized memory. 

## 8. Check for CIV ASAP
Safety checks should be performed as soon as the untrusted data is received. This is because it is very hard to ensure the safety once the data is propagated throughout the program, which leads to duplicated checks. 

Moreover, it prevent untrusted data from flowing to other compartments.

notes.title: Interrupt handling in Unikraft (x86)
notes.body:
#unikraft

On x86, `lidt %0` loads the IDT address into IDT register ([osdev]).

`traps_table_init` initialize the traps vector table, a.k.a the IDT ([osdev]). It writes into the `cpu_idt` table, with the corresponding trap index.

The function pointer to the handler in IDT is set to a stub, named `asm_trap_{trapname}` (defined by the macro `ASM_TRAP_SYM`). E.g., `asm_trap_page_fault`.

The stubs are defined in `cpu_vectors_x86_64.S`. Its implementation call the function with the name `do_{trapname}`. Declarations of these `do_*` functions can be found in `plat/x86/traps.c`. 

The following macro create implementations for the trap that actually call a `_raise_event_{event}` function. 
```c
#define DECLARE_TRAP(name, str, event)					\
void do_##name(struct __regs *regs)					\
{									\
	int rc;								\
	rc = _raise_event_##event(TRAP_##name, regs, 0);		\
	if (unlikely(rc < 0))						\
		uk_pr_crit("trap handler returned error: %d\n", rc);	\
									\
	if (!rc)							\
		do_unhandled_trap(TRAP_##name, str, regs, 0);		\
}
```

```c
DECLARE_TRAP   (debug,           "debug",                UKARCH_TRAP_DEBUG)
DECLARE_TRAP_EC(int3,            "int3",                 UKARCH_TRAP_DEBUG)
```

# References
- [osdev]: https://wiki.osdev.org/Interrupt_Descriptor_Table

notes.title: Invariants in Rust
notes.body:
#rust

Ralf Jung described two types of *invariants* in Rust in [this post](https://www.ralfj.de/blog/2018/08/22/two-kinds-of-invariants.html), *safety* and *validity*.

# Safety invariant
Essentially, *safety invariants* are the invariants of a particualr types, that must be upholded, such that that *no matter what safe code does, it must not cause undefine behaviors*.

One example of this for any primitive type `T`, the invariant is that the object having the type must be initialized (accesing unintialized data is an undefined behavior). Another example is that reference types must be aligned, non-null, and points to an allocated memory that have no other pointer accesses.


## Custom/higher-order safety invariants
There can also be *custom* safety invariants -- *higher-order* invariants that are not maintained by the compiler, but must be maintained by the unsafe code @bae2021rudra. For example, *Vec*, defined as 
```rust
pub struct Vec<T> {
    ptr: Unique<T>, // pointing to the heap-allocated backing store holding all the data
    cap: usize, // number of elements that fit the backing store
    len: usize, // number of elements that are actually initialized in the backing store
}
```
, must uphold that `ptr` must points to valid memory size of `cap*sizeof(T)`, . The difference between invariants of Vec and other primitive types is that it is defined by the owner, and that the implementer of the type and the unsafe users must uphold them.

More specifically, for those types, the Rust compiler only guarantee the corectnesses of the signature. Some higher-order invariants can related to (see @bae2021rudra): 
1. Logical consistency (e.g., respecting total ordering)

notes.body:
#literature
@aga2019invisipage

# Summary
Two page tables are assumed: one to map EPC pages, and the other is to map normal pages. The EPC page table is safely stored within the EPC, an only the enclave can maintain it. Moreover, page faults are handled to the in-enclave page fault handler, so that the faulting address is not learnt by the OS.

Based on  this, InvisiPage then support the oblivious *demand paging* for the EPC pages.  It supports the spilling of EPC pages into non-EPC memory, and uses ORAM to decide which pages to spill. 

It adapt ORAM primitives for paging, and introduce hardware optimizations to reduce the overheads of ORAM.


# Oblivious page management
The goal is to allows the OS to control how many pages that an are allocated to an enclave, but not which virtual address that are mapped.

First, it maintain two page tables, one to map the EPC pages, the other is for normal use. This approach already exists in @costan2016sanctum. However, the new thing is that it allows the OS to swap EPC pages into non-EPC memory *obliviously.

To do this, the enclave and the OS has to collaborate for memory management.
## Collaborative memory management
### Spilling EPC page to non-EPC
The OS provides interface to spill a list of provided virtual addresses to non-EPC memory (`opam_access(o-vpn[])`)

The ORAM tree is maintained by the OS in a separated tree data structure. This tree is indexed by the oblivious page number (`o-vpn`), which is essentially the block ID in the ORAM tree. 

On receiving the `opam_access()` request, the OS has to keep the requested pages *memory-resident*. The enclave runtime then spills/fetchs the EPC pages according the the ORAM algorithm. 

On a spill, data from EPC pages are copied into non-EPC pages. For fetches, data from non-EPC pages are copied into EPC pages.
For this step, there is one optimization introduced: only one page is copied from thea non-EPC into EPC memory. The rest of the non-EPC pages are reshuffle within the non-EPC memory.
To the OS, it only seems like a path is accessed. It cannot tell which page is actually copied into the EPC. 


The page table is retrofitted to store position map information.


### Freeing an EPC page
To free a EPC page, the OS request a free request to the enclave, but the actual page that get freed is schosen by the enclave.

@zhang2020klotski





# Noteworthy Arguments
## Positioning
- Previous solutions for controlled-channel protection are either (0) incomplete against attacks, (2) have incomplete protection for code and data, and (3) has high overheads.
- Incompleteness against attack:
    - TXS-based solutions @shih2017tsgx, , that tries to detect interrupts of enclaves, but there has been attacks that can trigger without enclave exit.

 -Incomplete protection for code and data
  - Some only protect data accesses @sasy2018zerotrace @drsgx
  - Other only protect code access @zizagger, and can be defeated fine-grained attack

- High overheads
  - @shinde2016preventing places sensitive code and data inside one page, but has high overheads (4000x)
 vim.lsp.diagnostic.show_line_diagnostics() - Obfuscuro @ahmad2019obfuscuro only support small code and data size (8KB).


- #todo Subpage-level code and data randomization




# Oblivious memory subsystem scheme
## Memory subsystem
Klotski's memory subsystem consists of three levels (akin to the actual memory subsystem). The first is the code and data caches, that has reconfigurable sizes, called the *vCache*. The second level is the ORAM *stashes* for code and data. The final layer is the *ORAM tree*.

The stash and the tree are parts of an ORAM scheme.

Memory from the higher level is evicted into the lower level, with some policies.

The main reason for *vCache* is to trade-off security for some performance. This is the main difference with Obfuscuro @ahmad2019obfuscuro vCache can be configure to be larger than the page size.
- Why do you need three levels, why not just configure the stash size then?
  - ORAM algorithms requires the stash to be certain sizes, or else it will not work (e.g., the path does not fit into the stash).
  - The stash in untrusted memory, an can span several pages. 

Is there a scheme for storing data into untrusted storage, like in @sasy2018zerotrace?
- This paper assume all memory is within the enclave, and there is no spilling into untrusted storage.


## Memory access hierarchy

### Logical addresses
Logical addresses are the address that the instructions use (i.e., virtual addresses).

Klotski use 32-bit addresses in their implementation, maybe to limit the number of entries in the software PT?

### Logical address translation
The program is instrumented to *translate* the logical address on every operations into *real address*, which is an address inside the execution cache.

Logical addresses are translated using a software page table using same method as real page table. The following function translates logical address into page table index:

``` cpp
size_t getRealAddress(size_t logicAddr){
    size_t index = logicAddr>>SHADOWPAGEWIDE;
    //if the page does not exist in cache,swap the page in
    if(!pagetable[index]){
        struct OramPool * oramPool;
        size_t blockIndex;
        if(isBigObject(index)){
            LOGIC_INDEX_TO_BLOCK_INDEX_FOR_BIG(index,blockIndex)
            oramPool = &DataPool_bigData;
        }else{
            LOGIC_INDEX_TO_BLOCK_INDEX(index,blockIndex)
            oramPool = &DataPool_smallData;
        }
        handleObliviousPageExchangeData(index,blockIndex,oramPool);
    }
    return pagetable[index]+logicAddr;
}
```
The address itself also seems to contain the block ID. `LOGIC_INDEX_TO_BLOCK_INDEX(index,blockIndex)` gets the correct block ID from the position map index.

In this translation function, if page is not in the page table, then it is not in the cache, so address translation happen. This is not what is described in the paper: a PTE also contains the path ID. Maybe this function is only used for static data...

The real translation function seems to be `dereference_data()`.

### ORAM access
On a page miss, ORAM access is triggered to fetch block into the vCache. 
First, the ORAM block (2KB *minipage*) is fetched in to the *stash*, and the position map is updated. The block is then moved to the vCache, and a block inside vCache is swapped out.  
#### Stash<->ORAM
Ring ORAM evict the blocks after $k$ accesses. On eviction, blocks inside the stash is flushed into the ORAM tree.

#### vCache<->Stash
The minipage is then swapped into the vCache, where a block is *randomly* evicted from the vCache to make space.

The paper argue that *LRU* cache eviction may leak information.

There is also a reconfigurable re-randomization of the vCache: the user can configure such that the vCache is flushed after $n$ accesses. 




## Address translation
Klotski uses a scheme to *translate* logical address to the actual address inside vCache, in the same way a MMU translate physical to virtual address.


```c
// virtual addr use in Klotski-instrumented program
loadImm R1, logicalAddr
call vPTE_lookup(R1)
// use pointer
load R2, R1 
...

v_addr vPTE_lookup(v_addr logicalAddr){
    vPTE_t vPTE = position_map_scan(logicalAddr);
    if (vPTE.cached)
        return vPTE.addr;
    else
        // slow path
       if (vPTE.in_stash) 
           vPTE = stash_fetch(vPTE.oramIndex);
       else
           vPTE = oram_read(vPTE.oramIndex);
       return vPTE.addr;
}
```

### Address translation

# Compiler & runtime
Compiler changes all memory instructions, call, return, into calls into the runtime functions. 
Implementation: [Here](https://github.com/nczhang88pan/KlotskiSGX/tree/master/klotski/llvmProgram/llvm/lib/Transforms/Instrumentation/Klotski)
Maybe the compiler transformation would looks like this:

```llvm
%0 = alloca 100
%1 = load ptr %arg1
%2 = add %1, 100
call foo()
store %2, ptr %0

---
%1 = call mmu_load(%arg1)
%2 = add %1, 100
call mmu_call(&foo)
call mmu_store(%2, %1)
```

The compiler also split code and data into blocks of 2KB, which is also the ORAM block size. The code is compiled as relocatable code, so that it can be relocated to any virtual addresses.
-  Why do you need relocatable code here?
-  What is effiective virtual address, why does it change at runtime?

The runtime functions acts as a memory subsystem: given a virtual address, it look up 


# ORAM Accesses
The paper uses Ring ORAM for its ORAM algorithm. However, there are several noteworthy extensions. Because the memory used for posmap (virtual page  table) and stash is in untrusted memory, attackers can find out which stash slot and posmap entry is accessed.

## ORead
An `ORead` operation is introduced to lineary scan over all data that must be touched to remain oblivious, similar to a `cmov`. The data is stored into a 256-bit  ymm registers. 1 register is reserved for reading unused data, and the remainings is used to store the required data.

NOTE: it is not exactly similar to `CMOV`, you only need to actually touch the data in `ORead`, but not write it back.

---

The `ReadPath` operation that read from ORAM path into stash uses this to bring data into the stash without revealing the actual bucket/block that is accessed.

For example, consider fetching of a path in traditional Ring ORAM. On each bucket along the path, a block is fetched, but discarded. On the block that contain non-dummy data, it is actually read into the stash. With visibility over stash and tree, the attacker can see that there is a read from the tree, following by a write into the stash. This means that the block that is just read contains the requested data.

By fetching all data into YMM registers, and delay the write back to the stash to the last moment, this can be hidden.

---

`LoadCache` that load an entry from stash into cache also needs this (for same reason above). It must scan over all stash entries, and only copy the one needed into the vCache.

## WriteStash
The WriteStash operation, that write into the stash, is also made oblivious. There are two potential leakage, when the attacker learns about the stash access:
1. If data is written into a slot, it means that the slot is empty, so it must have been evicted recently.
2. If data is written into a stash slot twice (without being read), it can be infered that the slot contained dummy blocks.  Is there actually dummy blocks in the stash?

To solve this, every (1) block must only be written once (before being reshuffled), and (2) a write to a slot must not reveal the last block being evicted
Klotski solve this by keeping a pointer to slot that is last written, and increment the pointer to the next slot at every write. When the pointer move to the last empty blocks, the stash is reshuffled.

```
      Spare stash ptr
            |
            v
| 2 | 5 | 3 | <empty> | 4 | <empty> | 
```

After write:
```
                      v 
| 2 | 5 | 3 | *6* | 4 | < empty > | 
```

Pointer moved to the last empty block, so reshuffle:
```
                           v
| 2 | <evited> | <evicted> | 6 | 4 | *1* | 
```

Reshuffling moves actual blocks to the begining and update the spare stash ptr.
```
                v
| 6 | 1 | 4 | 2 | <empty> | <empty> | 
```

[This blog post](https://zettelkasten.de/posts/creative-technique-within-zettelkasten-framework/) proposes a framework to think about [[ae6fatms|Zettlekasten]] notes.


1. Choose an idea and place it in the center.
2. Think of each leaf as an aspect of the thought that is needed to fully develop it. The thought blossoms like a flower.
  - Truth: Are there arguments for its truth? Is there empirical evidence for its truth? Is it free of self-contradiction?
  - Relevance: To whom is the thought important? To whom is it not?
  - Usefulness: What problem can be solved by the thought? Can it become a tool?
  - Beauty: How does the thought promote harmony and elegance?
  - Simplicity: How can you make the thought simpler and easier to understand? Can the thought be used to simplify something else?

- First reached definition: First node after this that redefine the register
UseNode contains :
- Reaching definitions: Nodes that this definition uses

notes.title: Limitations of Data-flow-based Dependence analysis
notes.body:
#analysis #compartmentalization #data-flow-analysis

Program compartmentalization techniques such as [@liu2017ptrsplit] often relies on dependence analysis to determine the data flow between code locations, then separate the program based code dependency. Commonly it is done by first identify all *control dependencies* of instructions, which form a reachable control-flow graph. Then, on the reachable control-flow graph, data-flow analysis is performed to find data dependencies.

[@lu2023practical] ([[literature/4zdjxws6]]) notes several limitations with such an approach:

First, control dependencies does not reflect all data dependencies.
- System calls and interrupt handlers is invoked at arbitrary time, and don't have a control-flow edge on the CFG. 
- Two control-independent functions can still pass data through global variables or shared memory.
[](2023-05-26_.md)
Second, data-flow analysis requires points-to analysis.
- Points-to analysis is expensive can cannot scale to large programs.
- Points-to analysis produces a large amount of false positive on large programs.

notes.title: ORAM Algorithmic Optimizations
notes.body:
#oram #oblivious

## Superblock
In ORAM, because accesses are always shuffled, the locality is terrible, because individual block's position is shuffled at every access.

Superblock optimization (@ren2013design) ensures that a group of blocks are always in the stash together. This group of blocks is called the *superblock*. Accessing a block in a superblock would brings all block into the stash, which improve the locality. Note that the number of blocks in a superblock can be smaller than the height of the tree. 

At initialization time, blocks on the superblock $S$ are placed on the same leaf. Whenever a block from the superblock is requested, the entire path is brought into the stash, so the blocks in $S$ is inside the stash. Like normal Path ORAM, the leaf index of the requested block in the position map is updated. This requested block is like a leader, which all blocks in the same superblock follow. Potition of blocks in the superblock are also updated to the leader block's path. Hence, when they are evicted, they would be evicted on the same leaf. 

### Security
@ren2013design (3.2.2) argues that this does not affect the security of ORAM. On each access, superblocks are mapped to a random leaf. Same as normal path ORAM, the observer can only see randomized path accesses, regardless of the superblock. 

### Why posmap update for blocks other than the requested block is fine in this case?
This is fine fine because the superblock can be seen as a single block in the ORAM access.

In a more generalized scenario, when updating the position for blocks inside the stash, the new position should be random, or *independent* of the block content/access pattern (not sure if this is correct).

Oblivious paging against controlled-channel
notes.body:
#tee #sgx #oblivous #controlled-channel

Oblivious paging is a direction to tackle the paging control-channel in SGX, by enabling the enclave with the ability to perform page table management. 


Previous work on this tries to implement *self-paging enclaves*. Self-paging enclaves let the enclaves manage their own memory mappings. Page faults to the enclave-managed pages are forwarded to the enclave fault handler, so the faulting address is hidden from the OS.





@aga2019invisipage uses two page tables, as inspired by @costan2016sanctum, where one table is maintained by the enclave, and the other is maintained by the OS. The OS-maintained page table is similar to the traditional one. The enclave page table is used for paging of EPC pages.
The memory for enclave page table is stored in the EPC, and 
An additional page table base register is added, and when an EPC page fault occur, the the private page table is walked instead.

@orenbach2020autarky argue that ORAM-based oblivious paging requires intrusive hardware modifications to the CPU, thus is not practical.

# Challenges
## Supporting for demand paging
Demand paging allows the OS to map the memory page into the address space only when the process actually touch the page. When it is touch, a page fault will be raised, informing the OS to map the page the the process's page table.

Demand demand paging obviously conflict with the goal of hiding page faults from the OS.

A simple solution is to statically separate public and private pages, such that fault from the enclaves are served by the enclave never served by the OS. This design creates an additional problem: it rob the ability to perform memory management from the OS. Once a private page has been mapped, the OS no longer hav the ability to reclaim the page from the enclave. A malicious enclave can prevent the OS from ever reusing the page. Moreover, once an enclave page is reclaimed, the OS can still learn about accesses on the page @aga2019invisipage.

notes.title: One sentence paper summary
notes.body:
#writing #reading

Most papers can be summarized into one sentence that capture the highest-level ideas. For instance,
> Obliviate introduces an data-oblivious file system using ORAM primitives.
> Capacity retrofit PAC and MTE primitives to enable capability-based access control for file and memory.

Ideas that cannot be consolidated into one sentence is either over-complicated, not well-defined, and not well-contained.

Knowing this has implications for both reading and writing.

First, when reading a paper try to find the main ideas of the paper and summarize it into one sentence.

Second, when writing papers, identify the core idea of the in one sentence first. This will determine the scope of the paper and avoid over-complicating things. Moreover, it allows for concise writing. Each sentence/paragraph should contributes to the main idea.

# Comparision critera
## Code & data
Some work provides protection to only data accesses, while other protect both code and data accesses.

## Granularity
Perfect trace, Cache-line, Page-level.


# Obfuscated execution techniques
The first line of defense is obfuscated execution ([[n9bxzpge]]), which guarantees that code and data accesses of a program looks the same, given a sensitive input.
They usually have high overheads and are considered impractical.


# Detecting page faults
One class of defense is to treat all possible page fault triggered by the OS as malicious. This requires that the enclave pages are statically determined and mapped to enclave. Hence, demand paging is not possible in this model.


Most of these defenses uses  Intel TSX [[dx7vz8d5]], due to its ability to supress page faults. 
For more details, see [[fvom56lw]]. 

Since their introduction, there has been attacks that can leak secrets _without_ explicitly triggering page faults #cite-needed. Hence, these defenses are incomplete to today's standard.

Another category of defense is to replace all memory instructions of the enclave (through compiler instrumentation) with requests to a reference monitor that make the actual request indistinguishable to attackers (e.g., using ORAM primitives).

notes.body:
#unikraft #os

# Enabling paging
Paging is enabled with the configuration PAGING, enabled by setting Platform Configuration -> Platform Interface Option -> Virtual memory API in `make menuconfig`.

`PAGING` option affects `plat/kvm/x86/setup.c`, where `mem_init()` would calls `init_paging()`. 
Then, `ukplat_pt_init` is called to initialize the page table.
- It calls `pgarch_init()` to initialize architectural-dependent info, such as checking 1GiB pages support, PAT support.


# Initializing paging
## `kernel_pt`
This global struct stores info for the initialization time kernel page table.

Later, a virtual address space (VAS) is created, which also points to this page table.
## `ukplat_bootinfo`
At build time, the linker prepare a `boot_info` structure.
Boot info contains a list of *physical* memory regions (kernel image, uninitialized memory, ...).

## `mem_init`
The function inserts the remaining memory from after the kernel image (after `__END`) to the remaining physical memory to the list of memory regions. This region flag is `UKPLAT_MEMRF_UNMAP`, which means that these pages are unmapped from the kernel page table, and are only mapped on-demand.
```c
rc = ukplat_memregion_list_insert(&bi->mrds,
		&(struct ukplat_memregion_desc){
			.vbase = PAGE_ALIGN_UP(__END),
			.pbase = 0,
			.len   = PLATFORM_MAX_MEM_ADDR - PAGE_ALIGN_UP(__END),
			.type  = 0,
			.flags = UKPLAT_MEMRF_UNMAP,
```

It then calls `paging_init`

## `paging_init` 
The function initializes the kernel's page table. On Linux, there is also the same function, but the process is a bit different  ([[cn9u3d79]]).

First, it calls `ukplat_pt_init`, which initializes the page table facilities, using a free memory region.
1. `pgarch_init()` setup the CPU features
2. `pgarch_pt_init` initialize the frame allocator and adds all physical memory to it.

After the page table

For every region with the flag `UKPLAT_MEMRF_UNMAP`, it unmaps them from the page table. Finally, it maps regions with the flag `UKPLAT_MEMRF_MAP` to memory. 



## `pgarch_pt_init`
Architectual-specific page table initialization is performed here. On X86, it reserves space for the frame allocator (`struct uk_falloc`), initializes the allocator, then adds the remaining physical memory to the frame allocator pool of memory.


# Page fault handler
The page fault handler is defined separatedly as `do_page_fault` in `common/x86/traps.c`. It calls `rc = uk_raise_event(UKARCH_TRAP_PAGE_FAULT, &ctx);` (more details is in event.h).

The handler for this event is found in `ukvmem/arch/x86_64/pagefault.c`, registered as
```c
UK_EVENT_HANDLER_PRIO(UKARCH_TRAP_PAGE_FAULT, vmem_arch_pagefault,
		      CONFIG_LIBUKVMEM_PAGEFAULT_HANDLER_PRIO);
```

See [[1k9i1cr3]] for more about Unikraft's interrupt handling.

with `ukvmem`, different page fault handlers can be registered for different VMAs. On a page fault. the VMA for the faulting address is looked up, then the VMA's registered page fault handler is called.

ukvmem enables APIs for virtual memory management. It creates Virtual Address Spaces (VAS), which contains smaller regions called Virtual Memory Areas (VMAs).

notes.title: Practical Program Modularization with Type-Based Dependence Analysis
notes.body:
#literature #analysis #compartmentalization
@lu2023practical

# Main arguments
Data-flow-based dependence analyses are impractical on large programs due to incorrect results and scalability issues, and A type-based dependence analysis avoid data-flow analysis.
- See [[dgdvhu1e]]
- The proposed approach can handle multi-entry, multi-threaded programs, and does not rely on points-to analysis.

Module-aware type-based dependence analysis enables practical dependence analysis. 
- If only the module boundaries are analyzed (function arguments and global variables), the inner complexity of module is does not matter.
- The proposed analysis only analyses the two types of typed-based data-flow, through function arguments and through global variable.

Module-based analysis and type-based analysis are complementary.
- Module-aware analysis complement type-analysis:
  - Previous type-only approaches @lu2019where are imprecise because they scan the entire program for a particular type.
  - There are modules in programs that has contain same types, but not related at all
  - The approach can further refine the CFI targets by using dependent module information
- Type-aware analysis improves module-aware analysis:
  - A module-only analysis would be highly imprecise (only identifying if module A can write into B), using the Type of argument further restrict the data flow, making it an effective approach.

The proposed analysis is effective and sound (as a dependence analysis)
- It is effective (in restricting data-flow) because it is difficult to form the data flow between modules with a given type, and that there are also modules between a module.
- It is sound (as a dependence analysis), since the approach will catch all cross-module data-flow if there is one.

The analysis improve upon existing security applications.
- When used for indirect call target reduction, it have high reduction rate on large application (up to 70% on firefox).
- It identify 90% write instructions in linux as non-sensitive, which can be enforced with techniques such as DFI, WIT. (No enforcement were tested).
  
# Observation
There is only two type of data-flow between modules: through function arguments/return values and through global variables 

# Type-based dependence analysis
The key idea is to perform type-based dependence analysis between modules (i.e., compilation unit). 
A *type-based dependence analysis* determine if modules of the programs may propagate the object of a certain types to a particular module.

The following types of dependencies are detected:

Direct (through argument):
- If M1 pass argument of type T1 to M2, there is direct data flow M1->M2.

Indirect (through global)
- If M1 write to global g type T, M2 read global type T, then there is data flow M1->g->M2.

Transitive:
- There can be chaining of cross-module data flow, e.g., M1->M2->g->M3->M4 

# The analysis
The analysis takes a pair of type and module <type,module>, and automatically all dependent modules. There are three main steps.
- The first step collect castable types into a CastMap. This is to handle unsafe casting operations in C/C++, all possible casted types are also considered in the data flow.
- The second step find out the direction and type of the data flow between two particular modules and store it into a `FlowMap`. Finding out the direction possible data flow ([[#direction]]).
- The final step compute dependent modules and the dependent types.

It is also observe that type-based indirect calls can be further refined using module-awareness. The author use an iterative method to refine the indirect call targets:
- In first iteration, find dependent modules of an indirect call
- Next, limit the type-based call target matching to only using the dependent modules.
- Repeat until no more refinement is made


## Finding data flow direction 
[]{#direction}

For two modules $M$, $V$, and a use $U$ of type $T$:
- If the use in $V$ is a *load* LLVM instruction, then the direction is $M->V$.
- If it is a $store$ instruction, then the direction is $V->M$.
- If it is the GEP instruction, also analyze the use of the instruction
- Else, it is bidirectional.

On struct types and pointer types, the types of the field is also analyzed. This is done through recursion on GEP instructions.

The result is stored in a structure called the $FlowMap$ that record Type, Direction of data flow between two modules.

## Type elevation
*Type elevation* is also proposed to improve the precision. The idea is that instead of using the type of the use site, which might have many false possitive, *elevate* it to the type of the containing struct.
For example, when an indirect call type $T1$ in a struct $T2$ is called, we first find the set of dependent modules using the type $T1$. Then, we find the dependent modules using the struct type $T2$. Finally, we *intersect* the two set to have a more refined dependent module set for the type $T1$.

This approach is unsound for container types (*base type*) that can be created from within the module, because cross-module data-flow will not find dependent module for those types. The paper suggests a simple *externality analysis*: If the base type is ever assigned (through `store` and initilizers), it cannot be used for elevation.

Essentially, it is just following chain of GEP instructions to get the outermost type as the *base type* (section 5)


# Implementation notes
## Type comparison
The authors found that type comparison in LLVM poses challenges: 
- Type may have different underlying memory objects so pointer comparison does not work
- The same struct type might have different variants, so string comparison may not work.
- Struct types may or may not have name.

## Unions
Union types is handled by using the union type itself, instead of the instantiated type. This hurts precision but guarantee soundness.
